event: Indigenous peoples inhabit the land that will become Canada.
Norse explorer Leif Erikson establishes a settlement at L'Anse aux Meadows in Newfoundland.
John Cabot explores the coast of Newfoundland for England.
Jacques Cartier claims the Gaspé Peninsula for France, beginning French exploration.
Samuel de Champlain founds Quebec City.
Treaty of Utrecht cedes parts of French territory in Canada to Britain.
Start of the Seven Years’ War (French and Indian War in North America).
Treaty of Paris ends Seven Years' War; France cedes most of its North American territory to Britain.
Quebec Act recognizes French civil law and the Catholic religion in Quebec.
Constitutional Act splits Quebec into Upper Canada and Lower Canada.
War of 1812 between Britain (including Canadian forces) and the United States.
Rebellions in Upper and Lower Canada against colonial governance.
Upper and Lower Canada united into the Province of Canada.
Confederation: Canada becomes a self-governing dominion with four provinces.
Manitoba becomes a province; Northwest Territories acquired by Canada.
British Columbia joins Confederation.
Completion of the Canadian Pacific Railway; North-West Rebellion led by Louis Riel.
Klondike Gold Rush begins.
Canada enters World War I as part of the British Empire.
Canada signs Treaty of Versailles independently, joining the League of Nations.
Statute of Westminster grants Canada legislative independence from Britain.
Canada declares war on Germany, entering World War II independently.
Canadian Bill of Rights is enacted.
Canada adopts the maple leaf as its national flag.
First Quebec independence referendum fails.
Canada Act passed, patriating the constitution and enacting the Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
Second Quebec independence referendum narrowly fails.
Canadian government apologizes for residential school system abuses.
Justin Trudeau becomes Prime Minister.
Discovery of unmarked graves at former residential school sites sparks national reckoning.
